docs.lead_paragraph: Alarmed by an Oregon law allowing physician-assisted suicide, the House of Representatives today passed a bill that would make it a Federal crime for doctors to prescribe drugs to help terminally ill patients end their lives. The vote was 271 to 156. Seventy-one Democrats joined 200 Republicans in supporting the legislation. Twenty Republicans, 135 Democrats and 1 independent voted against it.

headline.main: HOUSE BACKS BAN ON USING MEDICINE TO AID IN SUICIDE

docs.abstract: House, alarmed by Oregon law allowing physician-assisted suicide, passes, 271-156, bill that would make it Federal crime for doctors to prescribe drugs to help terminally ill patients end their lives; House bill says use of controlled substances to alleviate pain or discomfort is 'legitimate medical purpose' even if use of such substance may increase risk of death; Atty Gen Janet Reno in June 1998 said Federal Government would not take action against Oregon doctors who assist in suicide and comply with procedures of state's law; House measure would in effect overrule Reno (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Israel Opens Passage From Gaza to West Bank The first ''safe passage'' route between the Gaza Strip and the West Bank was opened for Palestinians, reconnecting the divided halves of the Palestinian world and taking a step forward in the peace effort revived by Prime Minister Ehud Barak, who took office in July. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: THESE days, Julia Rothstein can't be sure where her son will end up living. She said that after being evicted for rowdyism from his apartment in Huntington this summer, her 48-year-old son, diagnosed as a manic depressive, found shelter in hospitals, a crisis center and his car. A month ago he was taken to the psychiatric unit of the Nassau County Medical Center after the police charged him with driving 100 miles an hour. Mrs. Rothstein hoped that he would get the medical treatment he needed there, but a judge agreed to have him discharged after only a month, before her son could be stabilized on his medication.

headline.main: Patching the Safety Net For the Mentally Ill

docs.abstract: Article on two trends, managed care and deinstitutionalization, that are becoming detriments to severely mentally ill Long Island residents in need of long-term care; only psychiatric hospital remaining is Pilgrim State, which continues to reduce number of beds despite long waiting list; photo (M)
